module.p: falbh leave, depart, go away is an intransitive verb, with verbal noun falbh

section.p:
The principal parts of falbh are –
falbhaidh – future independent ie. will leave
dh’falbh – past independent ie. left
falbh – verbal noun ie. leaving

section.p:
The subject of falbh usually refers to a human (or a group of humans), acting under their own volition. –
pedagogical examples –
Ceart! Tha mi a’ falbh.
Right! I’m going/off/away. td. 176
A bheil fhios agad gu bheil Màiri a’ falbh le Iain?
Do you know that Mary is going (out with) with Ian? [ie. courting] td. 278
Nuair a ràinig mi an doras bha an duine air falbh.
When I reached the door the man had gone. td. 278
older pedagogical examples –
Tha mo mhàthair a’ sgrìobhadh litreach gu m’athair a tha air falbh. Thubhairt mo mhàthair, “An téid thu do bhocsa nan litrichean leis an litir seo, Iain?” “Théid,” ars Iain, “falbhaidh mi an dràsda”. [...]
My mother is writing a letter to my father who is away. My mother said, “Will you go to the postbox with this letter, John?” “Yes, I will,” said John, “I will leave now.” [...] td. 5
examples from Gairm –
[...] “Thainig e mach á sgoth-luing le na siùil gheala. Cha robh facal Gàidhlig aige. [...] Tha thu coltach ris [...]. ’Be an samhradh a bh’ ann. [...] Bha mise ’g ionnsachadh na Beurla. Cha robh esan math air a’ Ghàidhlig. [...] Aon latha dh’fhalbh e. Anns an t-soitheich.” [...]
[...] “He came out of a yacht with white sails. He didn’t have a word of Gaelic. [...] You look like him. [...] It was the summer. [...] I was learning English. He wasn’t good at Gaelic. [...] One day he left. In the boat.” [...] td. 170–1, le Iain Mac a’ Ghobhainn
[...] Dh’fhàs a guth na bu làidir. “Tha aon rud cinnteach, chan fhalbh aon choigreach le mo leanabh. Cha teid i gu aon dannsa, tha sin cinnteach. Tha. Tha. Na bi smaoineachadh gun teid, a leanaibh. Chan eil fhios agad mu ’n deidhinn, mar a th’ agamsa.” [...]
[...] Her voice grew louder. “One thing is certain, not one stranger will leave [go out?] with my child. She will not go to a single dance, that is certain. It is. It is. Do not be thinking that you will, child. You don’t know about them, as I do.” [...] td. 171, le Iain Mac a’ Ghobhainn
other examples from modern usage –
[...] Thachair cùisean glè aithghearr an uair sin. Thàinig heileacoptar le lorg-phoileas agus dh’fhalbh e le na h-eucoraich. [...]
[...] Things happened very quickly after that. A helicopter came with a detective and he left with the criminals. [...] td. 101
[...] An ath mhadainn dh’fhalbh Rob agus cha robh sgeul air fad na bliadhna. Bha amharas againn gur e a mhurt a rinn sgalagan an uachdarain, agus nuair a chuala sinn gun dh’fhalbh an t-uachdaran fhèin agus Mab gu Tasmania, cho-dhùin sinn gur e a chiont a ghluais e. [...]
[...] The next morning Rob left and there was no trace of him all year long. We suspected that the landlord’s men had killed him, and when we heard that the landlord himself and Mab had left for Tasmania, we concluded that it was guilt that motivated him. [...] td. 115
[...] Bha e ag ullachadh a’ bhaidhsagail nuair a thàinig a mhàthair far an robh e: “Nach bu chòir dhuit a dhol a shealltainn a bheil d’ athair a’ tighinn,” ars ise. Dh’fhalbh Dan, cha b’ ann dha dheòin, gu mullach a’ chnuic air cùl a’ chlachain. Bha athair air cluinntinn gu robh eathar ag iasgach a-mach bho chladach Ealasword, agus chaidh e a dh’fheuchainn am faigheadh e iasg. [...]
[...] He was preparing the bicycle when his mother came to where he was: “Shouldn’t you go and see if your father is coming,” she said. Dan left, reluctantly, for the top of the hill behind the village. His father had heard that a boat was fishing out of Ealasword beach, and he had gone to see if he could get fish. [...] td. 123

The subject sometimes refers to a vehicle under human control –
pedagogical examples –
Bidh am pleuna a’ falbh aig còig uairean.
The plane will take off at 5 o’clock. td. 278
examples from modern usage –
[...] Bha trèana ag ullachadh airson falbh agus dh’fhuirich Ailig gus am faca e duine òg le feusag is glainneachan dubh a’ dol dhan trèana leis a’ chèis. [...]
[...] A train was preparing to leave and Alec waited until he saw a young man with a beard and dark glasses going into the train with the case. [...] td. 108

Or to a natural force –
pedagogical examples –
Dh’fhalbh a’ ghaoth leis a’ phàipear.
The wind blew away the paper. td. 278
other examples from modern usage –
“[...] Chaidh iad gu tràigh le eathar bheag rubair agus laigh e anns a’ ghrèin agus leig iad leis an tìde-mhara falbh leis an eathar. [...]”
“They went to a beach with a little rubber boat and he lay down in the sun and they let the tide take the boat out. [...]” td. 106

The subject can refer to a unit of time, especially in the relative ... a dh’fhalbh –
pedagogical examples –
anns na bliadhnachan a dh’fhalbh
in past years td. 278
... air a stèidheachadh air an àm a dh’fhalbh
based upon the past td. 278
Bu chòir dhuinn cuimhne a chumail beò air na làithean a dh’fhalbh.
We should keep the memory of bygone days alive. td. 278

Other examples of subjects which are hard to categorise –
pedagogical examples –
Bha a shùilean a’ falbh air feadh a’ choithionail.
His eyes were going throughout the congregation. td. 278
The most basic use of falbh is as a strict intransitive verb with a subject but without any complements.

Some examples –
pedagogical examples –
Dh’fhalbh iad an-dè.
They left yesterday. td. 176

other examples from modern usage –
[...] Bha trèana ag ullachadh airson falbh agus dh’fhuirich Ailig gus am faca e duine òg le feusag is glainneachan dubh a’ dol dhan trèana leis a’ chèis. [...]
[...] A train was preparing to leave and Alec waited until he saw a young man with a beard and dark glasses going into the train with the case. [...] td. 108
[...] “’S e thu fhèin a phàigh e airson mo mhurt?” “Mar tha fios agad, cha do rinn mi sin. Cha robh càil na mo rùn ach an t-airgead fhaighinn. Ach na bi smaoineachadh nach fheuch e a-rithist.” Bha Carol sàmhach airson greis. Mu dheireadh thuirt Kevin: “Tha m’ iuchraichean nam phòcaid. Falbh agus faic an ceas a tha ’n ciste a’ chàir.” [...]

But don’t be thinking he won’t try again.” Carol was quiet for a while. Eventually, Kevin said: “My keys are in my pocket. [...] Thog i an daga le clobhd a bha sa chiste agus thug i a-steach e gun meur a chur air. Chuir i am falach e sa chidsin mus deach i air ais gu Kevin. “Bheil thu gam chreids’ a-nis?” dh’fhaighnich e. “Feumaidh sinn falbh. Tha caraidean agam an Lunnainn.” Leum Kevin a-mach às an leabaidh. “Falbhaidh sinn anns a’ bhad,” ars esan. [...]
[...] She lifted the pistol with a cloth that was in the boot and brought it inside without leaving a fingerprint on it. She concealed it in the kitchen before she went back to Kevin. “Do you believe me now?” he asked, “He have to leave. I have friends in London.” Kevin jumped out of the bed. “We will leave immediately,” he said. [...] td. 110

[...] Thug i am poca plastaig dha Kevin. “Fuirich aig an taigh gus an tig mi dhan Ghearasdan.” Anns a’ bhad ’s a dh’fhalbh e, chaidh i dhan chidsin agus le clobhd thog i a’ ghlainne a thug i dha Kevin nuair a thàinig e chun taighe. Thug i a’ ghlainne agus an daga suas gu rum Ailig. [...]
[...] Carol put what was in the trunk in a plastic bag. [...] She brought the plastic bag to Kevin. “Wait at home until I come to Fort William.” As soon as he had left, she went to the kitchen and with a cloth she picked up the glass that she had given to Kevin when he had come to the house. She took the glass and the pistol up to Alec’s room. [...] td. 110
[...] Bha an Seanailear cho feargach ’s gun thòisich e a’ dèanamh plana airson Rob a leòn cho dona ’s nach cuireadh e dragh air tuilleadh. Goirid an dèidh seo chuala e gu robh Mab a’ coinneachadh Roib, agus bha adhbhar eile aige airson dèiligeadh ris a’ phoidsear. Aon oidhche chuir e dà dhuine gu taigh an Deucoin airson Rob a phronnadh, ach nuair a bhris iad a-steach bha leabaidh Roib falamh. Bha e air a bhith a’ cadal ann an taigh nàbaidh bho dh’innis Mab dha an cunnart san robh e. An ath mhadainn dh’fhalbh Rob agus cha robh sgeul air fad na bliadhna. [...]
[...] The General was so angry that he began to make a plan to injure Rob so badly that he would not worry him any longer. Shortly after this he heard that Mab was meeting Rob, and he had another reason to deal with the poacher. One night he sent two men to the Deacon’s house to peat up Rob, but when they broke in Rob’s bed was empty. He had been sleeping in a neighbour’s house since Mab told him the danger he was in. The next morning Rob left and there was no trace of him all year long. [...] td. 115
falbh also occurs with a range of different prepositional complements and quasi-complements.

module.p:
Pedagogical examples –
Dh’fhalbh a’ ghaoth leis a’ phàipear.
The wind blew away the paper. td. 278 Non-volitional subject.

Examples from Gairm –
[...] Dh’fhàs a guth na bu làidir. “Tha aon rud cinnteach, chan fhalbh aon choigreach le mo leanabh. Cha teid i gu aon dannsa, tha sin cinnteach. Tha. Tha. Na bi smaoineachadh gun teid, a leanaibh. Chan eil fhios agad mu ’n deidhinn, mar a th’ agamsa.” “Carson nach do bhàsaich thu o chionn leth-cheud bliadhna,” dh’ éigh Màiri. Bha i smaoineachadh air na gnothaichean ud fhathast! “Greas ort leis an tea,” ars a màthair. [...]
[...] Her voice grew louder. “One thing is certain, not one stranger will leave [go out?] with my child. She will not go to a single dance, that is certain. It is. It is. Do not be thinking that you will, child. You don’t know about them, as I do.” “Why did you not die fifty years ago,” shouted Mary. She was still thinking about those matters! “Hurry up with the tea,” said her mother. [...] td. 171, le Iain Mac a’ Ghobhainn

Other examples from modern usage –
[...] Thachair cùisean glè aithghearr an uair sin. Thàinig heileacoptar le lorg-phoileas agus dh’fhalbh e le na h-eucoraich. [...]
[...] Things happened very quickly after that. A helicopter came with a detective and he left with the criminals. [...] td. 101
“[...] Chaidh iad gu tràigh le eathar bheag rubair agus laigh e anns a’ ghrèin agus leig iad leis an tìde-mhara falbh leis an eathar. Nuair a bha iad mu mhìle bhon chladach thòisich an t-eathar a’ call a gaoithe, agus ged a thòisich an gille air iomradh gu tìr, chaidh an t-eathar fodha agus cha robh snàmh aig bean mo bhràthar ...”
“They went to a beach with a little rubber boat and he lay down in the sun and they let the tide take the boat out. When they were about a mile from shore the boat started to lose air, and though the boy began to row ashore, the boat sank and my brother’s wife was unable to swim ...” td. 106 Non-volitional subject.
[...] ’S ann a bha inntinn air Magaidh. Bha bliadhna bho thòisich e a’ falbh leatha, a’ bhliadhna a fhuair e àrdachadh gu inbhe lioftanant san Nèibhi agus a thug e Magaidh dà uair a Lunnainn. Chosg e dha a h-uile sgillinn a bha aige, ach cha do rinn sin dragh sam bith dha. ’S ann a bha e a-nise a’ smaoineachadh gun iarradh e oirre a phòsadh. Bha inntinn dùinte dhan a h-uile càil ach sin. [...]
[...] His mind was on Maggie. It was a year since he had started going out with her, the year in which he had got promoted to the level of lieutenant in the Navy and had taken Maggie twice to London. It had cost him every penny he had, but that did not bother him at all. He was not thinking that he would ask her to marry him. His mind was closed to everything but that. [...] td. 124
[...] Thàinig an t-aithreachas air ais. Carson a bha e a’ caitheamh a h-uile sgillinn a bha aige air Magaidh, agus gun càil aig a phàrantan ach am peinnsean? Carson nach deach e a choinneamh athar a bha trì fichead bliadhna ’s a deich? Carson a dh’fhalbh e leis a’ bhàrr agus leis an iasg? [...]
[...] The regret came back. Why was he spending every penny he had on Maggie, while his parents had nothing but their pension? Why did he no go to meet his father who was seventy? Why did he leave with the cream and the fish? [...] td. 124–5

Examples from modern usage –
[...] “Na lorg thu duine a mhurtadh mi fhathast?” ars ise. “Tha Ailig air an t-airgead a phàigheadh dha mu thràth. Nach b’ fheàrr dhuit fhàgail? Nach fhalbh thu còmh’ rium fhìn?” [...]
[...] “Did you find a man to kill me yet?” she said, “Alex has paid the money to him already. Shouldn’t you leave him? Won’t you leave with me?” [...] td. 109
[...] Thòisich an cabhadh ach chum Dan e fhèin blàth a’ smaoineachadh air taigh Magaidh, an teine mòr fosgailte a bh’ ann, agus an drama a bhiodh aice dha. Ach nuair a ràinig e an taigh cha robh solas ann, agus bha an doras glaiste. Smaoinich e gur e a dhol a-steach do thaigh a nàbaidh a rinn i. Bha leth an taighe aig cailleach a bha càirdeach dhi, agus dh’fhaighnich e an robh Magaidh a-staigh. ’S e gàire car neònach a rinn a’ chailleach. “Chan e a thigeadh oirre,” ars ise. “Dh’fhalbh i còmhla ri fear le càr mòr dearg.” [...]
[...] The snow began but Dan kept himself warm thinking about Maggie’s house, the large open fire that was there, and the dram that she would have for him. But when he reached the house there was no light on, and the door was locked. He thought that she had gone into her neighbour’s house. Half of the house belonged to an old woman who was related to her, and he asked if Maggie was inside. The old woman gave him a rather strange smile. “[??]” she said. “She left with a man in a big red car.” [...] td. 124

Pedagogical examples –
Dh’fhalbh iad oirnn.
They left us. td. 278

falbh air iteig wing, fly off, cf. iteag
feather, plume

Examples from modern usage –
Aon mhadainn dh’fhalbh e dhan Spàinn le làraidh mhòr làn mhuirsgeanan-caola.
One morning he left for Spain with a big lorry full of razor clams. td. 104

Pedagogical examples –
falbh a dh’iarraidh ruideigin
go to fetch/get something td. 176

Examples from modern usage –
[...] An ath mhadainn dh’fhalbh Rob agus cha robh sgeul air fad na bliadhna. Bha amharas againn gur e a mhurt a rinn sgalagan an uachdarain, agus nuair a chuala sinn gun dh’fhalbh an t-uachdaran fhèin agus Mab gu Tasmania, cho-dhùin sinn gur e a chiont a ghluais e. Ach ’s ann a bha e a’ smaoineachadh gu robh fios aig Mab càit an robh Rob air falach agus bha e airson a bhith cinnteach nach biodh gnothaich aice ris tuilleadh. [...]
[...] The next morning Rob left and there was no trace of him all year long. We suspected that the landlord’s men had killed him, and when we heard that the landlord himself and Mab had left for Tasmania, we concluded that it was guilt that motivated him. But what he was thinking was that Mab knew where Rob was hiding out and he wanted to be sure that she would have no business with him any longer. [...] td. 115
[...] Bha e ag ullachadh a’ bhaidhsagail nuair a thàinig a mhàthair far an robh e: “Nach bu chòir dhuit a dhol a shealltainn a bheil d’ athair a’ tighinn,” ars ise. Dh’fhalbh Dan, cha b’ ann dha dheòin, gu mullach a’ chnuic air cùl a’ chlachain. Bha athair air cluinntinn gu robh eathar ag iasgach a-mach bho chladach Ealasword, agus chaidh e a dh’fheuchainn am faigheadh e iasg. Bha am biadh air rations anns an là ud. [...]
[...] He was preparing the bicycle when his mother came to where he was: “Shouldn’t you go and see if your father is coming,” she said. Dan left, reluctantly, for the top of the hill behind the village. His father had heard that a boat was fishing out of Ealasword beach, and he had gone to see if he could get fish. Food was being rationed in those days. [...] td. 123

falbh ’na* smùr moulder, decay, disintegrate, cf. smùr
dross, dust

module.p: falbh departure is a masculine common (verbal) noun.

Pedagogical examples –
Ceart! Tha mi a’ falbh.
Right! I’m going/off/away. td. 176
A bheil fhios agad gu bheil Màiri a’ falbh le Iain?
Do you know that Mary is going (out with) with Ian? [ie. courting] td. 278
Bha a shùilean a’ falbh air feadh a’ choithionail.
Hie eyes were going throughout the congregation. td. 278
Bidh am pleuna a’ falbh aig còig uairean.
The plane will take off at 5 o’clock. td. 278

Examples from Gairm –
[...] “Thainig e mach á sgoth-luing le na siùil gheala. Cha robh facal Gàidhlig aige. [...] Tha thu coltach ris [...]. ’Be an samhradh a bh’ ann. ’S bhiodh sinn a’ falbh còmhla ri chéile, a-measg nan cnoc. Cha robh càil ann ach boltradh. Bha mise ’g ionnsachadh na Beurla. Cha robh esan math air a’ Ghàidhlig. [...]”
“He came out of a yacht with white sails. He didn’t have a word of Gaelic. [...] You look like him. [...] It was the summer. And we would be going out together, among the hills. There was nothing but fragrance. I was learning English. He wasn’t good at Gaelic. [...]” td. 170–1, le Iain Mac a’ Ghobhainn

Pedagogical examples –
Tha i air falbh.
She’s left/gone/away. td. 176
Nuair a ràinig mi an doras bha an duine air falbh.
When I reached the door the man had gone. td. 278

Older pedagogical examples –
Tha mo mhàthair a’ sgrìobhadh litreach gu m’athair a tha air falbh.
My mother is writing a letter to my father who is away [from home]. td. 5 static locative, ie. temporary absence

section.p: air falbh away, off, gone is a directional adverbial phrase, cf. air on

module.p:
Pedagogical examples –
air falbh on taigh
away from home td. 279

section.p:
Examples from Gairm –
Ma rannsaicheas sinn air ais fada gu leòir chì sinn nach robh sgoilean anns an Oban gus an ochdamh linn deug. Bha an sgoil bheag a b’ fhaisge air anns a’ Chill Mhóir cóig mìle air falbh, agus tha e coltach gu robh an sgoil sin air an fheadhainn bu shine an Earra-Ghaidheal.
If we research back long enough we will see that there were no schools in Oban until the eighteenth century. The closest little school was in Kilmore five miles away, and it appears that that school was one of the oldest in Argyll. td. 363

p.en: dismiss, dispatch, post (a letter), remove, shed, turn
